case_vignette: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because they are concerned about his “strange behavior”. The boy was born at 39 weeks gestation via spontaneous vaginal delivery. He is up to date on all vaccines and is meeting all developmental milestones. The parents state that he has always been a solitary child without many friends, but that recently, he has been having behavioral problems that seem to be unprovoked and are occurring more frequently. The child will throw a tantrum for no reason and does not respond to punishment or reward. He also has a 'strange obsession' with collecting rocks that he finds on his way to and from school, so much so that his room is filled with rocks. His teachers say he “daydreams a lot” and is very good at art, being able to recreate his favorite cartoon characters in great detail. On assessment, the patient does not make eye contact with the physician but talks incessantly about his rock collection. The child’s grammar and vocabulary seem normal, but his speech is slightly labored.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been throwing tantrums for no reason, and I don't listen when I'm punished or rewarded.
Have you had any other symptoms such as difficulty sleeping, changes in appetite, or any physical symptoms?
No, I haven't had difficulty sleeping, changes in appetite, or any physical symptoms.
Have you been taking any medications or supplements recently?
No, I haven't been taking any medications or supplements.
Have you had any family history of mental health conditions such as anxiety or depression?
I don't know about any family history of mental health conditions like anxiety or depression.
Have you had any recent changes in your daily routine or environment?
No, there haven't been any recent changes in my daily routine or environment.
Have you had any recent stressful events or changes in your life?
No, I haven't had any recent stressful events or changes in my life.
Have you had any recent travel or exposure to new environments?
No, I haven't traveled recently or been exposed to new environments.
Have you had any recent changes in your sleep patterns or sleep quality?
No, my sleep patterns and sleep quality haven't changed recently.
Have you had any recent changes in your appetite or eating habits?
No, there haven't been any changes in my appetite or eating habits.
Have you had any recent changes in your physical activity level or exercise routine?
No, there haven't been any changes in my level of physical activity or exercise routine.
Have you had any recent changes in your academic or social environment?
No, there haven't been any recent changes in my academic or social environment.
Have you had any recent changes in your diet or nutrition?
No, there haven't been any recent changes in my diet or nutrition.
Have you had any recent changes in your stress levels or stress management techniques?
No, my stress levels and the way I handle stress haven't changed recently.
Have you had any recent changes in your mood or emotional state?
Yes, I've been having unprovoked tantrums more frequently.
Final Diagnosis: Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD)

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A client has been experiencing frequent unprovoked tantrums and has been refusing to listen to punishment or reward. They have not reported any difficulties with sleeping, changes in appetite, or physical symptoms. There is no history of taking medications or supplements, and no family history of mental health conditions has been reported. Additionally, there have been no recent changes in daily routine or environment, no recent stressful events or life changes, and no recent travel or exposure to new environments. There have been no recent changes in sleep patterns, sleep quality, appetite, eating habits, physical activity, exercise routine, academic or social environment, or diet and nutrition. The client also reports that stress levels and the way they handle stress have not changed recently.
trial_0.summarized_frq: The most likely diagnosis is Oppositional Defiant Disorder (ODD).
